are an adjoining town and village on the

coast. Known for being one of the few (or only) places on the east coast in England where the sun can be seen to set over the sea, the two places combine ancient heritage with traditional English seaside resort thrills.
is an 85 mile long coastal road that stretches from
. The road runs directly around the border of the town, with the

(or "Oasis Way") leading off into the centre. A scenic and enjoyable route, though difficult for HGVs at places.

It is also possible to reach Hunstanton by
from the neighbouring village of Heacham. However, be aware that this is a narrow gravel road with no markings and is prone to flooding in poor weather conditions.
Although without a station of its own since 1969, Hunstanton is connected directly to King's Lynn railway station by numerous bus services, including the Norfolk Green 10/11 and Coasthopper.
The Hunstanton area is relatively small and therefore there is only really the need to walk. To get to other villages, the Coasthopper bus is recommended.

value: - this famous, unique geological phenomenon that stretches from the new town into the old village beaches is a true 'postcard picture' place.
- the arch of this Norman chapel dating from 1272 is now all that remains, but it is still an intriguing historical site.
- a lighthouse only by name, as the actual beacon was removed in 1922, this building is unusual in appearance and lies on the border between the town and village.
directions=Sedgeford is signposted at Lavender Corner on the main road into Hunstanton

content=Bed and breakfast overlooking the North Norfolk coast. Set in 3 acres of park and woodland looking over the coast from the village of Sedgeford.  Villages such as  Burnham Market, Brancaster, Thornham and Holme are a few minutes drive away.
